body: Another mysterious issue is that the "Regression Test" header is eaten in the docstring. For example, if you look at [python/mxnet/symbol_doc.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/symbol_doc.py#L81), to check the doc for `Dropout`. Comparing with what doc we currently have [online](http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.Dropout). The "Regression Test" header somehow disappeared.
Closing for now due to inactivity.
Tagging with `HowTo` and closing for now.

We now have a `HowTo` tag for issues. We will be tagging issues that looks like common practice with this, and periodically go through the tagged issues and summarize the solutions into the howto or FAQ section of the doc.
In the new module API, you can force re-bind with new batch size.
Thanks for providing the link to patch.

The [record io](http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html#extension-multiple-labels-for-a-single-image) now support multi labels.
Tagging with `HowTo` and closing for now.
mx.mod.Module does. mx.model is deprecated and doesn't. It should be easy to switch

Closing due to inactivity.
We now have a stochastic depth example with module API in examples.
Please try the new module API for bucketing.

this is easy to do: just split it into two nets. the first one is your pre trained layers. and the second one is your last layer. the input of the second one is the output of the first one. it is easy to implemented.

Hi,
I would like to know if you guys really enforced the batch_size and the val_batch_size to be the same size (in ipython notebook the kernel dies, maybe a seg fault ?).
I am asking because from a theoretical point of view if you enforce that the users wont be able to use cross-validation methods like K-Fold or Jack Knife where the amount of data in validation is smaller than in training (so the batch_size would also be...).

Just to clarify, I ran across this while doing a cross-validation using mxnet. When the number of folds is 2 meaning that the amount of data in training and validation is equal everything is fine but if I raise the number of folds the kernel dies.
use gpu?
there is grad_scale param for output layers

You need to write your own op for this.
Look at src/operators/crop-inl.h for example

Or it's easier to use custom op, examples/numpy-ops/custom_softmax.py

use `infer_shape` to help you debug/understand.

``` python
# network definition.
input_x = mx.sym.variable('input_x')
embed_layer = mx.sym.Embedding(data=input_x, input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=num_embed, name='vocab_embed')

# infer_shape
input_shape = {'input_x' : (batch_size, xx, xx)} # choose it by yourself.
embed_layer.infer_shape(**input_shape) 
```

@morningpig917 These days I'm too busy with a deadline. `cufftComplex` is stored as a structure of two floats so we can store the Tensor as [real_1, imag_1, real_2, imag_2,...] and directly cast it to cufftComplex.

@wd929 That was due to some incompatible changes in `SoftmaxOutput` lately. Could you try to add `preserve_shape=True` when constructing `SoftmaxOutput` to see if it works?

@xlvector @piiswrong: Torch and TensorFlow have standalone padding layers that support reflective padding etc and padding that isn't applied to all sides. This has many uses, particularly for the likes of style transfer where zero padding is more likely to introduce edge artifacts. It obviously comes at a greater memory cost (as its not merged as part of pooling/convolution), but sometimes you would rather have more control.

I'm thinking of adding a mx.pad layer based on [tf.pad](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.11/api_docs/python/array_ops.html#pad). Let me know if you have thoughts on this layer, otherwise will just make a PR in the next few days.

@sbodenstein Sounds good! Thanks.

an easy fix is 

``` python
ctx = mx.cpu()
new_args = dict()
new_auxs = dict()
for k, v in arg_params.items():
    new_args[k] = v.as_in_context(ctx)
for k, v in aux_params.items():
    new_auxs[k] = v.as_in_context(ctx)
```

I know your issue. You pre-installed old MKL lib before which does not support MKL dnn API yet. By default, if you installed anaconda2, there will a old MKL lib in it. You need to 
1. remove old MKL version
2. when do make, see if mklml package is downloaded
3. export  export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:<MXNET ROOTDIR>/mklml_lnx_2017.0.0.20160801/lib

Pls let me know if it works.

Also would it better to make LiveBokehChart a internal class of PandasLogger?
Having something that's not a callback in mx.callback can be confusing

Ok it works.
This is going to be a freqent problem for users though. Basically mkldnn is not compatible with anaconda, which a lot of users use.
Is it possible to set the linker order so that it works with anaconda?

I've got some examples I can put in.  Adding it to module should be pretty straightforward.

I think PandasLogger & LiveBokehChart belong separate for a couple reasons:
1) I think it'll be useful to attach multiple live charts onto the same training run -- e.g. one showing speed, another showing loss, another showing validation metrics.  Or in some cases we track lots of different validation metrics.  This is easy to do through composition the way the classes are structured -- you instantiate multiple BokehChart objects and connect them to the same PandasLogger.  I imagine there should be other LiveBokehChart sub-classes that make these patterns easy.
2) The PandasLogger is likely to be useful by itself without any charts.  You can run this without a notebook, and it's trivial (one line of code) to save the dataframe as a .csv for offline analysis of the run.

That said, I think we can simplify the common case by having the BokehChart instantiate its own PandasLogger if one isn't passed in during construction.
@sbodenstein Thanks very much!

Thanks for suggestion. I did some debug. Actually this is because if anaconda is installed with mkl, numpy and related python will call the mkl and iomp5 lib in anaconda which is pre-defined. 
find library=libiomp5.so [0]; searching
search path=/root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/../../../..   (RPATH from file /root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packag     es/numpy/core/multiarray.so)
trying file=/root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/../../../../libiomp5.so

Because of this, the old MKL version in anaconda will be initialized and loaded so when calling new API, it will be wrong. 
     62803: calling init: /root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/../../../../libmkl_avx2.so 
     62803:  
     62803: python: error: symbol lookup error: undefined symbol: scalable_malloc (fatal)

led: (status) == (E_SUCCESS) Failed creation convert_to_int with status -1 for buffer: fwd_filter_data   @ MKLConvolutionOp

ConvolutionOp 

It is not issue of mkldnn compatible with anaconda. It is the issue when installing 2 different MKL version in system to cause annoying. The quick way to resolve this is remove mkl in anaconda until anaconda integrate the latest MKL2017. Pls refer to https://www.continuum.io/blog/developer-blog/anaconda-25-release-now-mkl-optimizations 

Since I believe anaconda will integrate the new MKL2017 soon, this issue will disappear automatically. I will put this into README as known issue. Also I will continue to look at this to see if have better w/a. 

But I think this should not block the PR merge, right? Pls let me know.

label = mx.sym.Reshape(label, shape=(-1,))

@sxjscience How to do it?

You can first check the gradient using functions in `test_utils.py` and write some test cases. Later you can submit a pull request containing the implementation of this OP. (Also it would be better if you can provide an example showing how to use this OP, e.g, the example of Compact Bilinear Pooling). You can do it if you have time.
your data iter must return mx.io.DataIter(data=[mx.nd.array(...)],...)

@piiswrong, @xlvector: its actually a larger project than I thought at first to write an efficient pad layer for n-dimensional tensors (and won't have time to do it).

The cases of interest are almost always for images (in which case only two of the four dimensions are padded), so I propose a layer `mx.image_pad`. This takes a tensor `(n, c, h, w)`, and parameters:
- `mode`: padding mode, can be "constant" (pad with 0), "reflect", "replicate" (same as Torch)
- `padding`: a matrix `[[pad_top, pad_bottom], [pad_left, pad_right]]`

In the future, a layer `mx.pad` could be written that deals with the general case (and will require a more verbose syntax for the common image case). This layer still replicates the [three torch layers](https://github.com/torch/nn/blob/master/doc/convolution.md) `SpatialZeroPadding`, `SpatialReflectionPadding` and `SpatialReplicationPadding`.

What are your thoughts?

For everyone's information, hereby I would like to share my solution to this problem. Although the structure of my customized networks is different, I also encountered the same error, i.e. "Shape of labels does not match shape of predictions".

I agree with @Godricly  that this is kind of a bug of the metric. Even we have reshaped the label to 1D vector, the metric will use the shape provided by the data batch, i.e. (1, 500,) in your case. Hence, to address this issue, the straight way is to modify your customized DataIter code to make sure the labels provided are a 1D vector.

However, if you have labels for each time step, the solution above doesn't work. Here is another ugly trick for both cases. Just modify the codes in the metric.py (of course, you need root/sudo permission) to squeeze the labels. The squeeze function will remove the single dimension. If I remember correctly, there is one line like "label = labels[i].asnumpy().astype("int32")". Below it, you could add a new line "label = label.squeeze()". I know this sounds crazy, but it works anyway.

Hope my reply would help you guys.
